document.title: Connecticut Elementary and Secondary Social Studies Standards

2A11C165CAF444F4B027509368E67C76.description:
Evaluate the role of various media platforms such as television, newspapers, and social
media in shaping reactions to events (e.g., Vietnam War, Tiananmen Square, fall of the
Berlin Wall, Arab Spring, Russo-Ukrainian War, 2016 and 2020 U.S. Presidential Elections).

7C2DA81AAD7A4EA3A16A54D84BD22917.description:
Explain how free-trade alliances and agreements have affected economic growth
in different nations in the late 20th century and 21st century (e.g., standard of living,
e-commerce, intellectual property, outsourcing, multinational organizations).

F5CBDA35BE074E0A92C0DB6F5A5E8335.description:
Analyze the role of comparative advantage in international trade in the late 20th century
and early 21st century (e.g., natural resources, labor availability, infrastructure, capital
goods, climate).

2ECD0E38C7404D559238963C08BBE4CD.description:
Describe an international economic policy in terms of intended and unintended market
outcomes (e.g., sanctions, free trade agreements, tariffs).

BA44E46B393744AF87A0E3C1B2D73022.description:
Analyze national and international responses to refugee crises sparked by natural
disasters, war, and genocide (e.g., Ukraine, Syria, Rohingya, Somalia, Latin America).

3253827EF3F54C97BDA35037D6E61CDD.description:
Analyze how individuals and groups advocate for economic, political, and social change
in international contexts (e.g., legislation, courts, resistance, protest, boycott, conscious
consumerism).

5CD33EE71B0F4F6C9221F75E5E5AC66D.description:
Evaluate the effectiveness of the international organizations in sustaining or undermining
global cooperation (League of Nations, United Nations, Organization of the Petroleum
Exporting Countries, North Atlantic Treaty Organization, European Union, Asia-Pacific
Economic Cooperation, International Court of Justice, Community of Latin American and
Caribbean States).

A0D3C24EBB74406E96B01D11B504188D.description:
Evaluate how economic globalization and the expanding use of scarce resources has led
to conflict and cooperation within and among nations and international organizations (e.g.,
Role of International Monetary Fund austerity policy in Jamaica, 2003 invasion of Iraq,
Annexation of Crimea, African Union, Central America-Dominican Republic Free Trade
Agreement, International Group of Seven).

1BEF9A62DFE548C6B845DC07F1FCDD6C.description:
Evaluate the influence of long-term climate variability on contemporary human migration,
settlement patterns, resource use, and land use at local-to-global scales (e.g., heat waves,
desertification, loss of biodiversity, fish migration, irrigation, wildfires).

0D9A39D26E54411F9D6217FBA06EEC7A.description:
Evaluate how the growth of the global economy has led to changes in settlement patterns
(e.g., urbanization, resource scarcity, immigration, emigration, war, industrial waste).

28975C0BB22D435696CACA100A4C104C.description:
Evaluate the multinational political and economic agreements that have led to changes in
cultural and environmental characteristics among and within nations (e.g., European Union,
Kyoto Protocol, Paris Agreement, North American Free Trade Agreement, Trans-Pacific
Partnership, International Monetary Fund).

E90812FE2C73443ABFDD0DD79D62AF69.description:
Analyze the multiple and complex causes and effects of national and global public health
issues (e.g., HIV/AIDS, Ebola, reproductive health, addiction, climate change, nutrition,
potable water, COVID pandemic).

BBB9B3741B90432880AC23F2360B9AE2.description:
Develop questions about strategies used to promote and extend human rights and their
significance in both historical and contemporary global contexts (e.g., litigation, lobbying,
protests, social media, economic sanctions, diplomacy).

20ADF210668F41B5A6CD9730F8BF8484.description:
Analyze the impact of scientific and technological change in the late 20th and early 21st
century (e.g., International Space Station, computer technology, vaccines and public health,
Global Positioning Systems, cellular technology, Artificial Intelligence).

CF653F4241DB4487A310B85F9689D9A0.description:
Analyze historical and contemporary examples of the formation, dissolution or restructuring
of governments (e.g., Soviet Union, Israel, Republic of Iran, Zaire, Cuban Revolution,
Sandinista National Liberation Front).

52C90FC6A03C41AA9CEAE5298B1D3A15.description:
Analyze means of protecting or limiting human rights in the 20th century (e.g., Universal
Declaration of Human Rights, United Nations Resolution 181, Partition of India, Dirty War in
Argentina, Cultural Revolution in China, Khmer Rouge, Stolen Generations in Australia).

8CC8A21864E8476F801434DBB0AD8368.description:
Analyze the impact of treaties and laws on the maintenance of national and international
order in the 20th century (e.g., Apartheid, European Economic Community, Camp David
Accords, Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty, Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, Latin
American Integration Association).

AF4DC1108B25430DBECB68D23AB084EA.description:
Analyze how developments in multimedia shaped the perspectives of individuals
and groups in the 20th century (e.g., comic books, communication technologies, film,
propaganda, public service announcements, radio).

262CFA96225A4DF5B10EEEEDF1E86AA2.description:
Analyze the complex and interacting factors that led to genocide during different historical
eras (e.g., Armenia, Uganda, Cambodia, Bosnia, Rwanda, Darfur).

7C544FEBD4A94569BD02629BEF44F84F.description:
Analyze complex and interacting factors that influenced the perspectives about
international laws and treaties in the Cold War era (e.g., United Nations, Geneva
Conventions, North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Warsaw Pact, Nuclear Non-Proliferation
Treaty).

14AF3EB3798544DCAF557C2BA570D631.description:
Examine ways in which decolonization altered the balance of power within and among
nations (e.g., independence movements, decline of European political imperialism,
economic imperialism, ascendency of United States and Soviet Union as leading world
powers).

11DCECC0F4CD4F6CB5D10500644D91C4.description:
Evaluate how resistance movements and decolonization were shaped by post-World War II
circumstances and broader historical contexts (e.g., India, Kenya, Vietnam, Korea, Algeria,
Indonesia, Hungary, Germany).

76D7E42C078B47938D8426DE0734A429.description:
Analyze how changes in military technology impacted the outcomes of various conflicts
throughout the 20th century (e.g., barbed wire, bio-chemicals, flamethrowers, submarines,
tanks, aircraft, computer technology, nuclear weapons).

5FA8C7AA4036498D816A36E52DEADA3A.description:
Develop a historical argument about the long-term causes and triggering events that led
to World War II (e.g., militarism, nationalism, Treaty of Versailles, Japanese imperialism,
appeasement).

27570751C0E34A4A89BAD87AE7643CAA.description:
Synthesize sources from the Holocaust to develop questions and explore the experiences
of survivors, victims, resisters, collaborators, bystanders, and rescuers (e.g., survivor
testimony, memoirs, government documents, museums exhibits, historical fiction, and film).

4283428F6FE6444B8FB37E23D12B2226.description:
Investigate the ways in which antisemitic beliefs and other discriminatory policies in Europe
led to the persecution and murder of millions of Jews as well as Roma, disabled people,
LGBTQ+ individuals, and political prisoners during the Holocaust (e.g., Nuremberg Race
Laws, Final Solution, Aktion T4).

8E421D24AA224C78B53DC538F9141FC6.description:
Evaluate how the causes and effects of World War I influenced global conflicts in the 20th
century (e.g., imperialism, industrialization, nationalism, collapse of empires, communism,
socialism, fascism).

D0CDEB70EDD644AF9EEA0133514E0D95.description:
Investigate how different groups have struggled to gain freedom, equality, and social
justice at the national and international levels (e.g., Nelson Mandela, Ho Chi Minh, Kwame
Nkrumah, Indian National Congress).

53B0B445E87F4ED7938E5D12BEAF1888.description:
Analyze how historical events during imperialism influenced migration patterns and
population distribution (e.g., Berlin Conference of 1884-1885, Royal Niger Company,
Monroe Doctrine, Battle of Port Arthur).

50D986145C4C4302A602C2B190F5B48C.description:
Explain the relationships between the locations of places and the impact of imperialism
using maps and other representations (e.g., social, cultural, economic, political).

A7BCBD6CEC614E4E85C8DFC1179DFBD8.description:
Analyze the complex and interacting cultural, religious, and racial factors that influenced
perspectives of imperialist policies (e.g., Rudyard Kipling, E. D. Morel, Dadabhai Naoroji,
Boxer Rebellion, Sepoy Rebellion).

897A3B4CF7C74C85932DCFEEBEA66EE8.description:
Evaluate how imperialism was shaped by rivalries between industrialized nation-states for
political and economic power (e.g., Japan, Great Britain, France, Belgium, Germany).

7431D8DB31954445B10BF8632780E9EA.description:
Analyze how access to resources resulted in imperialist policies that had a range of
costs and benefits for different groups (e.g., West African diamonds, Middle Eastern oil,
Congolese rubber, Indian spices, Panama Canal, Manchuria).

EAEFF7C106614BCFB1923F45F6C786DB.description:
Analyze how the Industrial Revolution impacted the balance of power among nations (e.g.,
Opium Wars, Sino-Japanese relations prior to and post the Meiji Reformation, Crimean War,
Zulu War, Mahdist War, Anglo-German naval arms race, Scramble for Africa).

E69C323FC4704D96BC8DF24338DD7663.description:
Evaluate how the cultural and environmental changes caused by industrialization
influenced spatial patterns of trade and land use (e.g., Enclosure Movement, Bombay
Spinning and Weaving Company, Treaty of Amity and Commerce, Suez Canal).

1B7EAB5AFA28417B977C8834293D796E.description:
Analyze the relationships and interactions between growing industry and physical systems
to explain reciprocal influences that occur among them (e.g., air pollution, hydropower,
mining, dredging).

CA862B67691E4551AE945512E9B178E7.description:
Analyze multiple and complex causes and effects of industrialization (e.g., geographic
features, technological innovations, access to capital, exploitative foreign policies and
impact on native populations, environmental degradation, population trends, labor
standards).

00B1017F66BF4F77863EDC6A6922C817.description:
Analyze how industrialization gave rise to new ideals and their related policies (e.g.,
laissez-faire, communism, feminism, socialism, utilitarianism, utopianism).

443F14A5A067439598B20C39B82BE2A5.description:
Analyze how theories of government developed in the Age of Enlightenment represented
new ideas about the balance between rights of the individual and power of the government.

2371D0302505464BBAD6B7E66BBE0148.description:
Evaluate the extent to which political and social change was advanced by women in the
Enlightenment and Scientific Revolution (e.g., Mary Wollstonecraft, Margaret Cavendish,
Maria Winkleman, Maria Merian).

7271F22D6BF342AB83C0F7C8924ECC41.description:
Demonstrate spatial awareness by creating maps to illustrate the environmental
characteristics and patterns of trade in early modern world history using digital technologies
(e.g., colonialism, enslavement, imperialism, revolution).

D25E770A4E324F0EA5F89C761A004917.description:
Analyze how the diffusion of Enlightenment ideas influenced revolutions (e.g., United States,
France, Haiti, Venezuela).

CF3AC58C330F47FD8D61E40C50A36D84.description:
Evaluate how the Enlightenment and Scientific Revolution shaped institutions in society
(e.g., deism, individual liberty, religious tolerance, reason, scientific method).

C4371CF1AF6E4138BFD98F19A4F8E7A9.description:
Describe how the Atlantic system affected global trade through cultural diffusion and
competition (e.g., de-emphasis of Silk Road, extraction of natural resources, growth of
transatlantic slave trade, colonization of the Americas).

ACDF982A4B5A44C8815D11DF2982D43C.description:
Evaluate the impact of settlement on the environmental and cultural characteristics of the
early modern world (e.g., hacienda, encomienda, Jesuit missionaries, East India Company,
Ottoman Empire, unification of Japan, Indigenous genocide).

5D02F2D15350413084EA699CD3D46063.description:
Analyze how current interpretations of cultural exchange of the early modern world are
limited by the availability of sources and the perspectives represented (e.g., accounts
by Gomes de Zurara, Conquistadors, Ogier Ghiselin de Busbecq, Francisco de Almeida,
Bartolomé de las Casas, Francis Xavier).

A66BE025EF4F4E2AAE4DED0384A46BC3.description:
Evaluate how historical events and developments were shaped by the movement of
individuals and groups during maritime exploration (e.g., Treaty of Tordesillas, Seven
Voyages of Zheng He, Columbian exchange).

F2D05EA961654E068909AFD2C0D42953.description:
Evaluate and implement strategies for individual and collective action to address global
problems in classrooms, schools, and out-of-school civic contexts.

03E848D06BAD4B5A9A2DC9EE84FD9C21.description:
Analyze the characteristics and causation of ongoing global problems, both past and
present, using a multidisciplinary lens.

A30972C352CC45E09CE45783C41F2CE0.description:
Present arguments and explanations that feature evocative ideas and multiple
perspectives about modern world history topics to reach a range of audiences and
venues outside the classroom using print, oral, and digital technologies.

A86A8CB3786A4D40B20B7CF73BBD0112.description:
Critique historical arguments and explanations while acknowledging the strengths
and weaknesses given the purpose and audience (e.g., credibility, bias, reasoning,
sequencing, details).

D8285A3AF90D40F392F7F19C8FAF5FF2.description:
Construct explanations using sound reasoning, correct sequence, relevant examples, and
pertinent details to contextualize evidence and arguments (e.g., chronology, causation,
procedure).

803A808AE8044CB08B2714B257A220FC.description:
Construct arguments using precise and knowledgeable claims, with evidence from
multiple sources, while acknowledging counterclaims and evidentiary weaknesses.

FFAD2D78128D42AEB861472425D795FB.description: Communicate Conclusions and Take Informed Action

FEA1F558B45C44ADA692A2E57CDB09CB.description:
Refine claims and counterclaims by pointing out strengths and limitations of arguments
and explanations (e.g., precision, significance, knowledge conveyed).

C1EE27EC5FFD4E00951D47CB7B37F773.description:
Organize and prioritize evidence directly and substantively from multiple sources in order
to develop or strengthen claims (e.g., detect inconsistencies).

DC5AA754D579465BBB4256BA442D4916.description:
Gather relevant information from multiple sources representing a wide range of views
and mediums while using the origin, authority, structure, context, and corroborative value
to guide the selection of credible sources.

23B5EB9305684F3D82D1891A9C62F2CD.description:
Apply disciplinary knowledge and practices to demonstrate an understanding of modern
world history content.

0381F203A3874F12990E5A4CB893A21A.description:
Determine the kinds of sources that will be helpful in answering compelling and
supporting questions, taking into consideration multiple points of view represented in the
sources, the types of sources available, and the potential uses of the sources.

ADCD8C256EBF4896BB8EE6E42CC035DB.description:
Explain how supporting questions contribute to an inquiry and how new compelling and
supporting questions emerge when engaging sources that represent varied perspectives.

F477C32CA68449E3A96976068EFC1BAC.description: Explain how a question reflects an enduring issue in Modern World History.
